g.text: client
server
client
server
client:
• supports mTLS authentication with X.509 certificates
• uses a self-signed or CA-signed certificate with a certificate extension containing a custom OID and
ASN1:UTF8String value that serves as a global client identifier in respect of the service it represents,
e.g., 1.2.3.4.5.6.7.8=ASN1:UTF8String:client._mhs._grip.foo.com
• the client's public key fingerprint is published on the client domain using DNS TXT record,
e.g., client._mhs._grip.foo.com IN TXT "v=grip1; h=sha256; f=d2abde240d7cd3ee6b ... e971"
server:
• supports mTLS authentication with X.509 certificates
• uses a CA-signed certificate with an appropriate Subject Alternative Name (SAN)
• uses a DNS SRV record to specify a host and port of the server, while identifies the respective service,
e.g., _mhs._tcp.bar.com IN SRV 100 1 2525 mhs-server.bar.com
• uses the information in the assertion to identify the requesting party (user)
1. The client generates a security token — a signed (using the client's private key) DNS-bound assertion
in JWT format with these claims: {iat, iss, aud, sub, jwks, dlgr{sub}, token}
• iat: the issued-at timestamp of the token
• iss: identifies who issues the token — CN from public client's certificate, e.g., foo.com
• aud: identifies the target service by the DNS SRV record, e.g., _mhs._tcp.bar.com
• sub: identifies the requesting party by email address, e.g., alice.baz.com
• dlgr{sub}: delegator — an authorized client A (e.g., client._mhs._grip.baz.com) that authorizes
client B (e.g, client._mhs._grip.foo.com) to act on behalf of the requesting party (e.g., alice.baz.com)
• jwks: holds the client's certificate public key in the JWK Set format (alternatively provide JWK Set by
URI using jwks_uri claim)
• token (optional): a tokenized digital resource (message, blob, security token from the previous hop, ...)
2. Send an HTTPS request to the server with the security token using mTLS
3. authorization decision
• the client is authenticated via the DNS using the TXT record and
the custom OID value from the public client's certificate
• verify the security token signature
• validate proof-of-possession
• verify the 'aud' claim
• validate the 'sub' claim, the domain part of the requesting party
email address and the domain part of the dlgr{sub} must match
• (optional) validate the tokenized digital resource
4. Return the HTTP response, typically with 200, 201 status code
